fields.text: My mother said every persimmon has a sun inside, something golden, glowing, warm as my face.
I thought the earth remembered me, she took me back so tenderly, arranging her dark skirts, her pockets full of lichens and seeds.
Long enough have you dream'd contemptible dreams, Now I wash the gum from your eyes, You must habit yourself to the dazzle of the light and of every moment of your life.
My clouded reflection eyes me like a bird of prey, the profile of night slanted against morning.
Talked my head off Worked my tail off Cried my eyes out Walked my feet off Sang my heat out So you see, There’s really not much left of me.
Fight was what I did when I was frightened, Fright was what I felt when I was fighting.
I said I wouldn't, dammit: No tears.  I'm stone. I'm flesh.
Not I, nor anyone else can travel that road for you, You must travel it by yourself.
